data.title: Historical Events in 1910
data.meta_description: Historical events from year 1910. Learn about 186 famous, scandalous and important events that happened in 1910 or search by date or keyword.
data.text:
Beatty Rear-admiral

British naval officer David Beatty is promoted to rear-admiral

Jan 1 England cricket underhand bowler George Simpson-Hayward takes 6-43 on debut with underarm lobs in 1st Test against South Africa in Johannesburg; SA wins by 19 runs

1st junior high schools in US opens (Berkeley California)

British miners strike for 8 hour working day

Stanley Cup, Dey's Arena, Ottawa, ON: Ottawa Senators beat Galt (ON), 3-1 for a 2-0 sweep of challenge series

1st international air meet in US held, in LA

Jan 10 Lunt-Fontanne Theater (Globe) opens at 205 W 46th St NYC

John Millington Synge's play "Deirdre of the Sorrows" premieres in Dublin

Constructions ends on the Buffalo Bill Dam in Wyoming

Germany & Bolivia end commerce and friendship treaty

Jan 19 US National Institute of Arts & Letters incorporated by Congress

Stanley Cup, Dey's Arena, Ottawa, ON: Ottawa Senators outclass Edmonton HC, 13-7 for a 2-0 sweep of challenge series

British-Russian military intervention in Persia

Opera "Germania" premieres in NYC

1st stumping by a 12th man in Tests (N C Tufnell, SAf v Eng)

Jan 25 Children initiate idea of planting trees in Jerusalem

Heavy rains cause floods in Paris

1st British labour exchange opens

Feb 1 Dragoumis government forms in Greece

Edmond Rostand's play "Chantecler" premieres in Paris

The Boy Scouts of America is incorporated by William D. Boyce

Elektra

English premiere of Richard Strauss' opera "Elektra"

Typhoid Mary Freed

Typhoid Mary [Mary Mallon] is freed from her first periods of forced isolation and goes on to cause several further outbreaks of typhoid in the New York area

John Galsworthy's "Justice" premieres in London

1st radio contest held (Philadelphia)

Misalliance

George Bernard Shaw's play "Misalliance" premieres in London

13th Dalai Lama (Thupten Gyatso) flees Tibet for British India to escape Chinese troops

South Africa Act

Gandhi supports the African People's Organisations resolution to declare the Prince of Wales day of arrival in South Africa a day of mourning, in protest against the South Africa Acts disenfranchisement of Indians, Coloureds and Africans

Wall of snow collapse in Cascade Mountain Range buries three passenger trains, killing 96, near Steven's Pass, Washington; 23 people survive the worst avalanche in US history [1]

Rockefeller Jr. Retires

John D. Rockefeller Jr. announces his retirement from managing his businesses so that he can be devoted full time to being a philanthropist at the Rockefeller Foundation

Avalanche at Bear Creek in Rogers Pass, British Columbia, kills 58 railway line workers - Canada's worst avalanche disaster [1]

Ramon Inclan's "La Farsa Infantil de la Cabeza del Dragon" premieres

Mar 5 Stanley Cup, Dey's Arena, Ottawa, ON: Montreal Wanderers beat Ottawa Senators, 3-1

Baroness Raymonde de Laroche of Paris becomes the 1st ever licensed female pilot

Pittsburgh Courier begins publishing

Mar 10 Republic of China officially abolishes slavery

Hobbs Scores 187

English cricketer Jack Hobbs scores 187 vs South Africa, his 1st international test hundred only to then get out hit wicket

Stanley Cup, Montreal Arena, Westmount, Quebec: Montreal Wanderers beat Berlin Dutchmen (ON), 7-3

Lakeview Gusher, the largest U.S. oil well gusher near Bakersfield, California, vented to atmosphere

Barney Oldfield uses a Benz to break the existing records at Daytona Beach Road Course (131.25mph)

Frederick Converse's opera "The Pipe of Desire" is the first American opera to be performed at the Metropolitan Opera, NYC

83Â°F highest temperature ever recorded in Cleveland in March

Chalmers Auto Co offers a new car to each leagues' batting champ

US forbids immigration to criminals, anarchists, paupers and the sick

Mar 26 William H. Lewis appointed US Assistant Attorney General

Fire during a barn-dance in ÃkÃ¶ritÃ³fÃ¼lpÃ¶s, Hungary, kills 312

Fabre Hydravion

First seaplane takes off from water under its own power, piloted by Henri Fabre from the Ãtang de Berre lagoon at Martigues, France

Mississippi Legislature founded The University of Southern Mississippi

Dumitru Dan (Romania) completes a 62,137 mile (100,000 m) walk

Highest mountain in North America, Alaska's Mt McKinley claimed to have been 1st climbed by 4 local men

1st race at the Playa Del Ray Motordrome, 1st US auto speedway, is held near Los Angeles, California

Second Labor Government

Australian General Election: the Commonwealth Liberal Party is defeated by the Australian Labor Party, headed by Andrew Fisher, who is able to form a majority government

Pan American Union forms

Taft's First Pitch

US President William Howard Taft begins tradition of throwing ceremonial first pitch on Opening Day of baseball season

William Howard Taft is first US President to throw out the 1st ball at a baseball game

Halley's comet seen by naked eye 1st time this trip (Curacao)

Cleveland Naps Addie Joss 2nd no-hitter, beats Chicago, 1-0

Apr 20 Halley's Comet passes 29th recorded perihelion at 87.9 million km

Cleveland Naps play 1st game at League Park, lose to Detroit Tigers 5-0

International Exhibition opens in Brussels, Belgium

German Catholic youth movement Quickborn forms

Belgian parliament rejects socialist motion for general voting rights

South African Party Established

Louis Botha and J. B. M. Hertzog establish the moderately nationalist South African Party promising equality of Britons and Boers

1st Night Flight

First night air flight by Claude Grahame-White takes place in England

Roosevelt Visits Amsterdam

Ex-US President Theodore Roosevelt visits Amsterdam

Cleveland Naps Addie Joss limits St.Louis Browns to 8 hits in 2-1 victory

Intercollegiate Athletic Association of the United States is renamed the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA)

Canadian Currency Act, 1910, receives Royal Assent

Royal Canadian Navy Established

Wilfrid Laurier passes the Naval Service Act, which creates the Royal Canadian Navy

George V

George V becomes King of the United Kingdom upon the death of his father, Edward VII

1st aircraft air display held (Hendon, England)

May 10 Halley's Comet closest approach to Earth in 1910 pass

May 10 The British House of Commons pass three major resolutions on political reform

Montana's Glacier National Park forms

Philadelphia Athletics pitcher Charles "Chief" Bender no-hits Cleveland Naps, 4-0

Second NAACP Conference

Second NAACP conference in NYC

Canada authorizes issuing of silver dollar coins

The last time a major earthquake happened on the Elsinore Fault Zone

US Bureau of Mines forms

Canada sets the designs for the 1-50 cent coins

Passage of Earth through tail of Halley's Comet causes near-panic

Meeting of Interest

Funeral for Britain's King Edward VII held in Westminster Abbey, has one of the largest assemblages of European royalty

Louis Botha becomes the first Prime Minister of the Union of South Africa

Reform of Prussian three-class voting system fails

Pope Pius X's encyclical on Editae Saepe, against church reformers

Cape of Good Hope becomes part of Union of South Africa

May 31 Glenn Curtiss flies from Albany to NYC

May 31 Union of South Africa declares its independence from the United Kingdom

Sportclub Enschede soccer club forms in Enschede, Netherlands; merge with Enschedese Boys to form FC Twente in 1965

1st roundtrip flight over English Channel (C S Rolls, England)

Jun 2 Pygmies discovered in Dutch New Guinea

A passenger on SS Arawatta throws bottle with note overboard (found June 6, 1983 in Queensland)

Dutch soccer club PEC forms in Zwolle; renamed FC Zwolle in 1990 and back to PEC Zwolle in 2012

Pilot Charles Hamilton makes 1st 1-day round-trip from NY to Philadelphia

Jun 13 William D Crum, a South Carolina physician, appointed US minister to Liberia

1st airship in service "Germany"

Jun 19 Father's Day celebrated for 1st time (Spokane, Washington)

The Firebird

Igor Stravinsky's ballet "The Firebird" for the Ballets Russes premieres at the OpÃ©ra de Paris, Paris

Jun 25 US Mann Act passed (no women across state lines for immoral purposes)

First Zeppelin Flies with Passengers

1st airship with passengers makes its maiden voyage; the Zeppelin LZ7-Deutscheland and gets stuck in some trees in Mount Limberg, Lower Saxony, injuring one crew member

Chicago's White Sox Park (later Comiskey Park) opens - St Louis Browns beat White Sox, 2-0

Jul 1 Union of South Africa becomes a dominion

Fight of the Century

"Fight of the Century": Jack Johnson beats James J. Jeffries by TKO in 15 in Reno, Nevada to retain his world heavyweight boxing title

Jul 4 In a mutual defense agreements, Japan and Russia delineate their spheres of interest in Manchuria

Jul 4 The US Congress pass the Mann-Elkins Act, an important piece of railroad reform legislation

Walter Brookins, flying a Wright biplane over Atlantic City, New Jersey, becomes 1st to fly an airplane to an altitude of 1 mile (actually reaching 6,175 feet or 1.169 miles) [1]

Cy Young Wins 500th Game

Cy Young wins the 500th game of his Baseball HOF career as the Cleveland Naps beat Washington Senators, 5 - 2, in 11 innings; only pitcher in MLB history to reach milestone

Kuyper Found Innocent

Committee finds Former Dutch Prime Minister Abraham Kuyper innocent of corruption in the so-called decorations affairs

Matador Juan Belmonte (18) kills his 1st bull

JWEL Hilgers is 1st Dutchman to fly above Dutch territory

Chicago Cub King Cole no-hits St. Louis, 4-0, in a 7-inning game

Jul 31 Pioneering Dutch aviator Clement van Maasdijk gives a flying demonstration

Coomb and Walsh Pitching Duel

MLB pitching duel; Philadelphia A's Jack Coombs and White Sox Ed Walsh pitch a 0-0 tie in 16 innings

NYC Mayor William J. Gaynor is seriously wounded in an assassination attempt

The US Army installs the first tricycle landing gear on the Army's Wright Flyer.

Chicago resident Alva Fisher receives US patent for an electric washing machine

Brooklyn Superbas and Pittsburgh Pirates play "the game of perfect symmetry" in baseball to 8-8 tie, both have 8 runs, 13 hits, 2 errors, 12 assists, 5 strikeouts, 3 walks, 1 hit baseman, and 1 passed ball

6th International Congress of Esperantists held in Washington, D.C.

US supported opposition brings down Madriz in Nicaragua

Japan annexes Korea after 5 years as a protectorate

Fred Clarke makes a record 4 outfield assists for Pittsburgh

Yellow Cab is founded.

Using twenty 137,000 candlepower arc lights, 2 amateur baseball teams play a night game at White Sox Park

Aug 27 Wash Red Killefer sacrifices record 4 times against Detroit

Nicholas I of Montenegro again proclaims himself king (first assumed power 1860) after his reign interrupted by Turkish rule

Japan changes Korea's name to ChÅsen and appoints a governor-general to rule its new colony

MLB New York Highlanders Tom Hughes pitches 9-1/3 no-hit innings, but loses to Cleveland 5-0 in 11; 1991 rule change removed credit for no-hitter [1]

Theodore Roosevelt makes a speech in Kansas advocating a 'square deal': property shall be 'the servant and not the master of the commonwealth'

Philadelphia Athletics' player Jack Coombs begins a record streak of 53 shutout innings

Saskatchewan (then Regina) Roughrider football club formed

In the Hague, the International Court arbitrates a fishing-rights dispute between the US and Newfoundland (still separate from Canada)

Great Idaho Fire destroys 3 million acres of timber

1st commercially successful electric bus line opens (Hollywood)

Symphony of A Thousand

Gustav Mahler's 8th Symphony ("Symphony of A Thousand") premieres in Munich with 1028 musicians

Sep 12 United States' 1st known female cop appointed, Alice Stebbins Wells by LAPD

Regina Rugby Club forms

Boers & Afrikaners win 1st general elections in Union of South-Africa

25,000 demonstrate in Amsterdam for general male/female suffrage

Get-Rich-Quick Wallingford

George M. Cohan's musical "Get-Rich-Quick Wallingford" premieres in NYC

Saskatchewan Rugby Football Union forms with an initial 9 team competition

Sep 22 The Duke of York's Cinema opens in Brighton. It is still operating today as the oldest continually operating cinema in Britain

1st test flight of a twin-engined airplane (France)

National Urban League founded as Committee on Urban Conditions Among Negroes by Ruth Standish Baldwin and Dr. George Edmund Haynes in New York City

Berkshire Cattle Fair held in Pittsfield Mass (1st state fair)

Oct 1 Explosion at LA Times kills 21

Oct 1 Regina Rugby Club (to become CFL Saskatchewan Roughriders) plays first game, losing to Moose Jaw Tigers, 16-6

1st 2 aircraft collision (Milan Italy)

Oct 2 Henry Wijnmalen flies to 2,800m altitude (world record)

Adoption of the Flag of Bermuda.

Oct 4 Portugal becomes a republic, King Manuel II flees to England

Portugal overthrows monarchy, proclaims republic

Braves beat Phillies 20-7

Baseball History

Nap Lajorie challenges Ty Cobb batting average with 8 hits, 6 were bunts as Brown's 3rd baseman Red Corriden played deep, Cobb still won

Howards End

E. M. Forster publishes novel "Howards End"

Soccer team KFC forms in Alkmaar

Oct 20 The hull of the RMS Olympic, sister-ship to the ill-fated RMS Titanic, launched from Harland and Wolff shipyard in Belfast, Ireland

Dr. Crippen is convicted at the Old Bailey of poisoning his wife and was subsequently hanged at Pentonville Prison in London.

Blanche Scott becomes the first woman to fly at a public event in the US at Fort Wayne, Indiana

Oct 23 Ritz Hotel in Madrid opens with 200 chambers and 100 bathtubs

Hamilton running back / kicker Ben Simpson lands CFL record 11 singles in Tigers 14-7 win over Montreal at Montreal AAA Grounds

Crisis

First issue of "Crisis" published by editor W.E.B. Du Bois

Nicholas II Visits Wilhelm II

Russian Tsar Nicholas II visits German Emperor Wilhelm II at Potsdam; they force tentative agreements on spheres of influence in the Middle East

Nov 4 Start of South Africa's 1st F-C game in Aust (v S Aust). It rained

SDAP/NVV initiate campaign for general males/female suffrage

The first air freight shipment (from Dayton, Ohio, to Columbus, Ohio) is undertaken by the Wright Brothers and department store owner Max Moorehouse.

1st Washington State election in which women could vote

Nov 8 For the first time since 1894, the US elects a Democratic Congress, including the first socialist ever to sit in Congress, Victor L Berger of Milwaukee

Nov 8 William H. Frost receives the first U.S. patent for an electrical insect destroyer

The date of Thomas A. Davis' opening of the San Diego Army and Navy Academy, though the official founding date is November 23, 1910.

1st possible movie stunt: man jumps into the Hudson river from a burning balloon

1st airplane flight from deck of a ship, Norfolk, Virginia

Ferenc MolnÃ r's play "Tester" premieres in Budapest

Revolution breaks out in Mexico, led by Francisco I. Madero

Arthur Knight patents steel shaft golf clubs

NY's Penn Station opens as world's largest railway terminal

The first US patent for inventing the traffic lights system is issued to Ernest Sirrine

Neon lights first publicly displayed (Paris Auto Show)

French troops occupy the Moroccan harbor city of Agadir

1st US city ordinance requiring white & black residential areas in Baltimore

Dec 19 Rayon 1st commercially produced in Marcus Hook, Pennsylvania

Explosion in coal mine in Hulton England, 344 mine workers dies

US postal savings stamps 1st issued

Luisa Tetrazzini sings to 250,000 people at Lotta's Fountain, San Francisco

Englebert Humperdink's opera "Konigskinder" premiers at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City

US tobacco industry produced 9 billion cigarettes in 1910
